question: What does the saponification value represent?

answers.a: The oil/fat contains long-chain fatty acids
answers.b: The oil/fat contains a high concentration of glycerol
answers.c: The oil/fat contains short-chain fatty acids
answers.d: The oil/fat contains unsaturated fatty acids

question: If 50 mL of HCl is required in the blank titration and 40 mL is required in the sample titration, what is the implication?

answers.a: 50 mL of HCl was consumed in the saponification process
answers.b: 10 mL of KOH was consumed in the saponification process
answers.c: 40 mL of KOH was consumed in the saponification process

question: What is the color change observed at the endpoint of titration using phenolphthalein?
Which of the following will cause an increase in saponification value?

answers.b: Using a longer chain fatty acid
answers.c: Using a shorter chain fatty acid
answers.d: Using a stronger acid for titration

question: Why is it important to use an excess of KOH in the saponification process?

answers.a: To ensure complete hydrolysis of the fat/oil
answers.c: To prevent the formation of glycerol
answers.d: To react with any free fatty acids present

question: What role does the solvent (ethanol) play in the saponification process?

answers.b: It reacts with KOH to form soap
answers.c: It reacts with HCl during titration

question: Which of the following would result in an incorrect saponification value?
What would be the effect of using sodium hydroxide (NaOH) instead of potassium hydroxide (KOH) in the experiment?

answers.a: It would increase the saponification value
answers.b: It would decrease the saponification value
answers.c: It would not affect the saponification value
answers.d: It would result in incorrect titration

question: What is the primary by-product of the saponification reaction?
How is the accuracy of the saponification value determination ensured?

answers.c: By performing both a sample and blank titration
answers.d: By using a larger sample size
